turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: He wants to know if you killed Freddie Miles and then killed Dickie Greenleaf?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: No I did not. I did not kill Freddie Miles and then kill Dickie Greenleaf. Is he accusing me?  Ask him if he's accusing me!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: He's already angry, I don't think --

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Just because he doesn't like Americans!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Can you imagine, if Dickie did kill Freddie, what must that be like? To wake up every morning, how can you? Just wake up and be a person, drink a coffee...?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Whatever you do, however terrible, however hurtful -- it all makes sense, doesn't it? Inside your head. You never meet anybody who thinks they're a bad person or that they're cruel.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: But you're still tormented, you must be, you've killed somebody...

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Don't you put the past in a room, in the cellar, and lock the door and just never go in there? Because that's what I do.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Probably. In my case it's probably a whole building.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Then you meet someone special and all you want to do is toss them the key, say open up, step inside, but you can't because it's dark and there are demons and if anybody saw how ugly it was...

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I keep wanting to do that -- fling open the door -- let the light in, clean everything out. If I could get a huge eraser and rub everything out... starting with myself... the thing is, Peter, if...

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: No key, huh?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I'm sorry. I was asleep. I must have fallen asleep.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You look ghastly, Tom. Are you okay?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Not guilty.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I'll fix some drinks.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Are you okay?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I'm fine.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Do you want me to stick around?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: It's okay.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Or I could come back.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Tom, are you okay?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: You try. You try talking to her.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Tom. Tom! Tell me, what's going on?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I give up.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Ask me what I want to change about this moment.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What do you want to change about this moment?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Hello. What are you up to?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: All kinds of things. Making plans.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Plans -- good, plans for tonight or plans for the future?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I don't know. Both. My plan right now is to go up on deck, look at the sunset. Come with me.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You go. I don't want to get dressed yet. Come back though. Come back.  You know, you look so relaxed, like a completely different person.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Well, that's entirely your fault. And, if I fall overboard, that'll be your fault too.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: How was it?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Good. But I think we should stay in here for the rest of the trip.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Was that Meredith?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Was who Meredith?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Meredith Logue. You were kissing somebody. Looked like Meredith.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Hardly kissing. Kissing off.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Didn't look that way -- you know -- from a distance.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I lied. To her. She thought she'd seen you.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Why lie?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Dickie and Peter, that's just too good gossip, isn't it?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Or Tom and Peter even.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Well that would be even better gossip.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Really, why?  Sorry, I'm completely lost.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I know. I'm lost, too. I'm going to be stuck in the basement, aren't I, that's my, that's my -- terrible and alone and dark -- and I've lied about who I am, and where I am, and so nobody can ever find me.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What do you mean lied about who you are?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I suppose I always thought -- better to be a fake somebody than a real nobody.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What are you talking about -- you're not a nobody! That's the last thing you are.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Peter, I... I...

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: And don't forget. I have the key.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: You have the key. Tell me some good things about Tom Ripley. Don't get up. Just tell me some nice things.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Good things about Tom Ripley? Could take some time!... Tom is talented. Tom is tender... Tom is beautiful...

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: You're such a liar...

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: ...Tom is a mystery...

turns.speaker: ROVERINI
turns.text: Dickie Greenleaf?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: ROVERINI
turns.text: Inspector Roverini. Can we come in?

turns.speaker: ROVERINI
turns.text: It's a terrible shock, eh? What time did Signor Miles leave yesterday?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I can't be absolutely sure -- 8? 9? We'd both taken on far too many drinks -- but it was dark, it was certainly dark when I walked him down to his car.

turns.speaker: ROVERINI
turns.text: So Signor Miles drove away and you did what?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I went to bed. Freddie's a big man, but I'm in trouble after a couple of drinks. I've suffered all day. Who found him?

turns.speaker: ROVERINI
turns.text: Senta. We have to ask you to stay in Rome.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Yes, if it's going to help, certainly.

turns.speaker: ROVERINI
turns.text: So, the Doctor, he has to make the --  -- come se dice?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Postmortem?

turns.speaker: ROVERINI
turns.text: Yes, exactly, but his first, his first conclusion was that Signor Miles was killed not later than seven o'clock yesterday evening.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Well, he certainly wasn't dead when he drove off in his car.

turns.speaker: ROVERINI
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Can we go up? Do you mind?

turns.speaker: ROVERINI
turns.text: Of course. What happened to your face?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: My scooter. I fell off. Getting chased by photographers.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: The telephone, the press, I've been, I'm feeling hounded -- do you think you could not give out my address?

turns.speaker: ROVERINI
turns.text: Never. We've had many requests and, of course, we say no -- even to your fiancée.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I really don't want to see anybody.

turns.speaker: ROVERINI
turns.text: Even your fiancée...?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Even her.

turns.speaker: ROVERINI
turns.text: What about Thomas Ripley?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: What about Ripley?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Yes, sure, we did go to San Remo. That was months ago.

turns.speaker: ROVERINI
turns.text: November, I thought.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Was it? Did you speak to Tom?

turns.speaker: ROVERINI
turns.text: November 7th is my information.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I don't remember the exact date.

turns.speaker: ROVERINI
turns.text: And when did you last see Signor Ripley?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: A few days ago.

turns.speaker: ROVERINI
turns.text: Does he stay with you here?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: ROVERINI
turns.text: No. Here is a pattern. Two days ago Freddie Miles is dead -- he leaves your apartment and is murdered. Yesterday a little boat is found in San Remo full of rocks, and the owner tells the Police it was stolen on November 7th. We look at hotel records and we see oh! Dickie Greenleaf is staying in San Remo and then our boatman remembers two Americans taking a boat.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: It's not a pattern, it's a coincidence. There must be fifty hotels in San Remo, there must have been a hundred people renting a boat on that day.

turns.speaker: ROVERINI
turns.text: 31 people.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: 31 people.

turns.speaker: ROVERINI
turns.text: That is Miss Sherwood now. Marge Sherwood.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Let her in, what's the difference? Let her in.  No, actually, no, I'd like it very much if you would ask her to come back later.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: ROVERINI
turns.text: May I ask... why would you speak to your friend and not your fiancée?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I think I just said. Ripley was handling some business for me, nor does Mr Ripley want to marry me. Nor did he ask me every day if I would marry him. And when.

turns.speaker: ROVERINI
turns.text: Do you have a photograph of Signor Ripley?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I'm not in the habit of carrying around photographs of my male friends.

turns.speaker: ROVERINI
turns.text: Now I think I have upset you. My English perhaps is coarse.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: It is a little coarse, yes.

turns.speaker: ROVERINI
turns.text: Sorry. No one has seen Signor Ripley since San --

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: I have!

turns.speaker: ROVERINI
turns.text: You have, yes.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: No, I have and so has Miss Sherwood, ask her! And if I could remember which hotel he was staying at -- the Goldoni! -- Tom was staying at the Goldoni.

turns.speaker: ROVERINI
turns.text: Good. The Goldoni. Yes -- you're right. A coincidence.  I look forward to our next meeting when I will be more careful with my English and persuade you to play me your saxophone. Alto.

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Absolutely.

turns.speaker: ROVERINI
turns.text: I have a witness who thinks they saw two men getting into Mr Miles' car. She wants to identify you in a -- confronto -- line-up.  Tomorrow then?

turns.speaker: RIPLEY
turns.text: Tomorrow.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: You got a .44 Magnum?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: That's an expensive gun.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I got money.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Some of these guns are like toys, but a Smith and Wesson, man, you can hit somebody over the head with it and it will still come back dead on. Nothing beats quality.  You interested in an automatic?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I want a .32. Revolver. And a palm gun. That .22 there.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: That's the Colt .25 -- a fine little gun. Don't do a lot of damage, but it's as fast as the Devil. Handy little gun, you can carry it almost anywhere. I'll throw it in for another $125.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: How much for everything.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: The .32's $150 -- and you're really getting a good deal now -- and all together it comes to, ah, seven eighty- five for four pieces and a holster. Hell, I'll give you the holster, we'll make it seventy-five and you've got a deal -- a good one.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: How much to get a permit to carry?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Well, you're talking big money now. I'd say at least five grand, maybe more, and it would take a while to check it out. The way things are going now $5.000 is probably low. You see, I try not to fool with the small-time crap. Too risky, too little bread. Say 6 G's, but if I get the permit it'll be as solid as the Empire State Building.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Nah, this'll be fine.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: You can't carry in a cab even with a permit -- so why bother?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Is there a firing range around?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Sure, here, take this card, go to this place and give 'em the card. They'll charge you, but there won't be any hassle.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: You in Nam? Can't help but notice your jacket?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Vietnam? I saw it on your jacket. Where were you? Bet you got to handle a lot of weapons out there.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Yeah. I was all around. One hospital, then the next.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: It's hell out there all right. A real shit-eatin' war. I'll say this, though: It's bringing a lot of fantastic guns. The market's flooded. Colt automatics are all over.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: They'd never get me to go back. They'd have to shoot me first.  You got anything to carry these in?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: You like ball games?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: I can get you front and center. What do you like? I can get you Mets, Knicks, Rangers? Hell, I can get you the Mayor's box.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Nah. I ain't interested.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Is that so?  But what do you think of Charles Palantine?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Who mam?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Charles Palantine. The man you want to volunteer to help elect president.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Oh, I think he's a wonderful man. Make a great, great President.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: You want to canvass?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Yes, mam.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Well, that's not exactly what the Senator has proposed. You might not want to canvass, but there is plenty more other work we need done: Office work, filing, poster hanging.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I'm a good worker, Betsy mam, a real good worker.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: If you talk to Tom, he'll assign you to something.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: If you don't mind, mam, I'd rather work for you.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Well, we're all working tonight.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Well, Betsy mam, I drive a taxi at night.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Well, then, what is it you exactly want to do?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: If you don't mind, mam, I'd be mighty pleased if you'd go out and have some coffee and pie with me.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Well, Betsy mam, I drive by this place here in my taxi many times a day. And I watch you sitting here at this big long desk with these telephones, and I say to myself, that's a lonely girl. She needs a friend. And I'm gonna be her friend.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I don't know...

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: It's just to the corner, mam. In broad daytime. Nothing can happen. I'll be there to protect you.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: All right.  All right. I'm taking a break at four o'clock. If you're here then we'll go to the corner and have some coffee and pie.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Oh, I appreciate that, Betsy mam. I'll be here at four o'clock exactly.  And... ah... Betsy...

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: My name is Travis.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Thank you, Travis.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: We've signed up 15,000 Palantine volunteers in New York so far. The organizational problems are becoming just staggering.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I know what you mean. I've got the same problems. I just can't get things organized. Little things, I mean. Like my room, my possessions. I should get one of those signs that says, "One of these days I'm gonna get organezizied"

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Travis, I never ever met anybody like you before.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I can believe that.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Where do you live?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Oh, uptown. You know. Some joint. It ain't much.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: So why did you decide to drive a taxi at night?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I had a regular job for a while, days. You know, doin' this, doin' that. But I didn't have anything to do at night. I got kinda lonely, you know, just wandering around. So I decided to works nights. It ain't good to be alone, you know.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: After this job, I'm looking forward to being alone for a while.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Yeah, well...  In a cab you get to meet people. You meet lotsa people. It's good for you.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: What kind of people?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Just people people, you know. Just people.  Had a dead man once.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: He'd been shot. I didn't know that. He just crawled into the back seat, said "West 45th Street" and conked out.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: What did you do?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I shut the meter off, for one thing. I knew I wasn't going to get paid. Then I dropped him off at the cop shop. They took him.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: That's really something.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Oh, you see lots of freaky stuff in a cab. Especially when the moon's out.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: The moon?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: The full moon. One night I had three or four weirdos in a row and I looked up and, sure enough, there it was -- the full moon.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Com'on, Travis. It's not that bad. I take lots of taxis.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I know. I could have picked you up.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Late one night. About three. At the plaza.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Three in the morning? I don't think so. I have to go to bed early. I work days. It must have been somebody else.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: No. It was you. You had some manila folders and a pink bag from Saks.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: You're right! Now I remember! It was after the Western regional planners were in town and the meeting went late. The next day I was completely bushed. It was unbelievable.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: If it wasn't for a drunk I would have picked you up. He wanted to go to the DMZ.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: The DMZ?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: South Bronx. The worst. I tried to ditch him, but he was already in the cab, so I had to take him. That's the law. Otherwise I would have picked you up.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: That would have been quite a coincidence.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: You'd be surprised how often you see the same people, get the same fare. People have patterns. They do more or less the same things every day. I can tell.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Well, I don't go to the Plaza every night.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I didn't mean you. But just ordinary people. A guy I know -- Dough-Boy -- met his wife that way. They got to talking. She said she usually caught the bus so he started picking her up at the bus stop, taking her home with the flag up.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: That's very romantic. Some of your fares must be interesting. See any stars, politicians, deliver any babies yet?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Well, no... not really... had some famous people in the cab.  I got this guy who makes lasers. Not regular lasers, not the big kind. Little lasers, pocket sized, small enough to clip your belt like a transistor radio, like a gun, you know. Like a ray gun. Zap.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: What hours do you work?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I work a single, which means there's no replacement -- no second man on the cab. Six to six, sometimes eight. Seventy-two hours a week.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: You mean you work seventy-two hours a week.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Sometimes 76 or 80. Sometimes I squeeze a few more hours in the morning. Eighty miles a day, a hundred miles a night.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: You must be rich.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: It keeps ya busy.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: You know what you remind me of?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: That song by Kris Kristofferson, where it's said "Like a pusher, party truth, partly fiction, a walking contradiction".

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I'm no pusher, Betsy. Honest. I never have pushed.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I didn't mean that, Travis. Just the part about the contradiction.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Oh. Who was that again?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: The singer?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Yeah. Yes. I don't follow music too much.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Kris Kristofferson.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: You didn't have to spend your money -- ?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: He'll, what else can I do with it all?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Travis, you haven't even played the record?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Yeah, well my stereo player is broke. But I'm sure the record is OK.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Your stereo broke? God, I could hardly stand that. I live on music.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I don't follow music much. I'd like to though.  Honest.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: So you haven't heard this record yet?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: No.  I thought maybe you could play it for me on your player.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I bought a couple of tickets.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: But this is a porno movie.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: No, these are the kind that couples go to. They're not like the other movies. All kinds of couples go. Honest. I've seen them.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Damn.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: What's wrong?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I forgot to get the Coca-Cola.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Where are you going?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I'm leaving.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: These are not the kind of movies I go to.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Well, I don't follow movies too much...

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: You mean these are the only kind of movies you go to?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: This is sort of high class...

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I mean porno movies.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Well... mostly...

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: My God!

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: We can go to another movie if you like, I don't care. I got money. There's plenty...

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: ...there's plenty of movies around here. I haven't seen any of them, but I'm sure they're good.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: No, Travis. You're a sweet guy and all that, but I think this is it. I'm going home.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: You mean you don't want to go to a movie?  There's plenty of movies around here.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: No, I don't feel so good. We're just two very different kinds of people, that's all.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: It's very simple. You go your way, I'll go mine. Thanks anyway, Travis.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: But... Betsy...

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I'm getting a taxi.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: What about the record?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Keep it.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Can I call you?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Hello, Travis.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Hello, Betsy.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I see where Palantine got the nomination.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Yes. It won't be long now. Seventeen days.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Well, I hope he wins.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: How are you, Travis? I read about you in the papers.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Oh, I got over that. It was nothing, really. The papers always blow these things up.  A little stiffness. That'll go away. I just sleep more, that's all.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: No, no, please. This fare's on me. Please.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Thank you, Travis.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Travis?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Maybe I'll see you again sometime, huh?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Tom, come here a moment.  I think this canvas report is about ready to go out. Check it out with Andy, and if he okays if, have a copy made for the campaign headquarters in every county.  And don't forget to add the new photo releases.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: The senator's white paper is almost ready, Bets. Should we wait for that?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Andy usually just sends those to the national media. The local press doesn't know what to do with a position paper until UPI and AP tell them anyway.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I think we should try to get maximum coverage for this new mandatory welfare program. Push the issues.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: First push the man, then the issue. Senator Palantine is first of all a dynamic man, an intelligent, interesting, fascinating man.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: You forgot "sexy".

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: No, I didn't forget "sexy".

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Just didn't get around to it, huh?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Oh, Tom, please.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Well, for Christsakes, you sound like you're selling... I don't know what... cars... not issues.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Have you ever wondered why CBS News has the highest ratings?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: More people watch it.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Alright, forget it if you're not going to be serious,

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: No, c'mon, I'm listening. I was just...

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Just what?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Kidding around... you know, fun.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Maybe if you'd try thinking once in a while, you'd get somewhere.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: With who?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Alright, now. You want to know why CBS has the highest ratings? You think their news is any different from NBC, ABC? It's all the same news. Same stories. Same order usually. What, you thought they had good news for people, right? You thought that's why people watched CBS? I'll tell you why people watch CBS. Cronkite. The man. You got it? Not the news, not the issues, the man. If Walter Cronkite told people to eat soap, they'd do it. We are selling cars, goddamn it.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Well, if Cronkite's so great, why don't we run him instead?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: That's the last. The finish. Period. Some people can learn. Some people can't. And you wonder why we never get serious --

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Sure we could run him. You realize he's already head of his block association.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Have you been noticing anything strange?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: No, why?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Why's that taxi driver across the street been staring at us?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: What taxi driver?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: That taxi driver. The one that's been sitting here.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: How long has he been there?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I don't know -- but it feels like a long time.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Try holding the match like this.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: This is gotta be a game, right?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: This I gotta see.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Ouch!

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Oh, are you all right?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I'm great. Always set my fingers on fire. If you want to see another trick. I do this thing with my nose.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: No. I just wanted to see if you could light it that way. The guy at the newsstand can.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Ah, yes, the guy at the newsstand, Mr. Asbestos...

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: He happens to be missing fingers. I first noticed when --

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Is he Italian?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: No, why?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: You sure he's not Italian?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: He's Black, OK?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Well, If he had been Italian, they could have been shot off. Sometimes the mob does that to teach guys a lesson, If they blow a job or something.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: As I said, he isn't Italian. Besides, I thought they just killed them.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Don't be naive. They can't kill everybody. They have different punishments for different things. Like, if they kill a stool pigeon, they leave a canary on the body. It's symbolic.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Why don't they leave a pigeon instead of a canary?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I don't know. Maybe they don't leave a canary. Don't be technical. What I'm saying is if this newsstand guy's Italian and his fingers are gone, maybe he's a thief.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: First, he's not Italian. Second he's not a thief. I noticed the fingers when he was getting my change -- the right change. Two of his fingers are missing. Just stubs. Like they were blown away. I was putting my change in my purse when I saw him get out a cigarette. I couldn't help watching. I was dying to see how he'd light it.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: With the other hand, right?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: No, stupid. With the stubs. That's the whole point.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I know that guy. His hand looks like a paw. An old Black guy, the newsstand at --

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: No, this is young -- well, I'm never sure how old Black people are -- but, anyway, he isn't old. That's for sure.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Show me how he did that again.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Betsy, come over here a moment.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: What is it? I'm busy.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Just follow me.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: No, I don't think so.  That's someone else.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Now look more closely. Look around the eyes and chin. See? See there?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: What is your name? My name is Travis.

turns.speaker: CONCESSION GIRL
turns.text: Awh, come off it, Pal.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: No, I'm serious, really...

turns.speaker: CONCESSION GIRL
turns.text: Ya want me to call da boss? Huh? That what you want?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: No, no, it's alright. I'll have a big Coca-Cola -- without ice -- and a large buttered popcorn, and...  ...some of them chocolate covered malted milk balls... and ju-jukes, a box. They last.

turns.speaker: CONCESSION GIRL
turns.text: We don't have ju-jukes. We don't have Coca-Cola. We only got Royal Crown Cola.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: That's fine.

turns.speaker: CONCESSION GIRL
turns.text: That's a dollar forty-seven.

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: First she did her make-up. You know, I hate it when they do that. I mean she does the whole works, the mascara, the eye-shadow, the lipstick, the rouge...

turns.speaker: DOUGH-BOY
turns.text: Not rouge. Blush-On, they call it.

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: The kind with a brush.

turns.speaker: DOUGH-BOY
turns.text: Yeah, that's Blush-On. My wife uses it,

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: Ask Travis. He's the ladies man.

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: Well, whatever the fuck it is, she used it. And then the spray perfume. You know, the real sweat kind -- and, on top of that, get this, right when we're crossing the Tri-boro bridge -- she changes her pantyhose!

turns.speaker: DOUGH-BOY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOUGH-BOY
turns.text: Could you see anything?

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: Well, she was trying to keep her skirt down, sort of, you know. But it was pretty obvious what she was doing. I mean, Christ, it was rush hour and the traffic's practically standing still.

turns.speaker: DOUGH-BOY
turns.text: What did you do?

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: Threw on the emergency, jumped the seat and fucked her brains out -- What do you think!  What do I have to do? Draw you a picture?

turns.speaker: DOUGH-BOY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: What was I supposed to do? I was watching in the rear view. You know, just checkin' traffic.  So howsit?

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: Sure. What do you think? She wanted to get out of the cab. I said "Look, you're in the middle of the fucking bridge..."

turns.speaker: DOUGH-BOY
turns.text: You said that?

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: Well, I said, "Lady, please, we're on a bridge..."

turns.speaker: DOUGH-BOY
turns.text: And what happened?

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: She stayed in the cab, what's she gonna do? But she stiffed me. A real skunk.

turns.speaker: DOUGH-BOY
turns.text: A real skunk.

turns.speaker: DOUGH-BOY
turns.text: Yeah. We went to Harvard together.

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: We call him Dough-Boy cause he likes the dollars. He'll chase a buck straight into Jersey.

turns.speaker: DOUGH-BOY
turns.text: Look who's talking?  Who else would stay up all night to catch the morning rush hour?

turns.speaker: DOUGH-BOY
turns.text: You run all over town, don't you, Travis?

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: Fuckin' Mau Mau land, that's what it is.

turns.speaker: DOUGH-BOY
turns.text: Well, you ever need one, I know a feller that kin getcha a real nice deal. Lotsa shit around.

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: The cops and company raise hell they find out.

turns.speaker: DOUGH-BOY
turns.text: Truck drivers bring up Harlem Specials that blow up in your hand. But this guy don't deal no shit. Just quality. If you ever need anything, I can put you in touch.

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: For a fee.

turns.speaker: DOUGH-BOY
turns.text: For a fee.

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: I never use mine. But it's a good thing to have. Just as a threat.

turns.speaker: DOUGH-BOY
turns.text: Well, if there's this many hackies inside, there must be lots of fares outside. And I'm gonna hustle 'em.

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: What ya gonna do with all that money, Dough-Boy?

turns.speaker: DOUGH-BOY
turns.text: Support my kids. Can you dig it?  Nice to meet ya, Travis. So long, Wizard. Say hello to Malcolm X for me.

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: ...he called up the Dispatcher last night. Charlie McCall, our dispatcher...

turns.speaker: DOUGH-BOY
turns.text: One-Ball McCall?

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: That's the guy. Eddie calls him up and says, "Hey, what do you want me to do. I'm over here at Poly Prep. I got a girl in the back and she doesn't have the fare. She wants me to come in back and collect. What should I do?

turns.speaker: DOUGH-BOY
turns.text: Fuckin' One-Ball.

turns.speaker: WIZARD
turns.text: And the kid says, "Yeah. She's about 19, good-lookin." McCall says, "What can I tell you?"

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Some fleet driver for Bell just got cut up. Just heard it on the radio.

turns.speaker: DOUGH-BOY
turns.text: Stick up?

turns.speaker: DOUGH-BOY
turns.text: Stick up?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: No, just some crazy fucker. Cut half his ear off.

turns.speaker: DOUGH-BOY
turns.text: Where.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: In the jungle. 122nd.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: DOUGH-BOY
turns.text: I mean, you handle some pretty rough traffic, huh?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I have.

turns.speaker: DOUGH-BOY
turns.text: You carry a piece? You need one?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Nah.  I suppose not.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: 20 bucks?

turns.speaker: DOUGH-BOY
turns.text: Yeah. Hey thanks. That's real nice, Travis.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: You looking for some action?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Well... I guess so.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: All right.  You see that guy over there?  His name is Sport. Go talk to him. I'll wait here.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Why you hang around with them greasers?

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: A girl needs protection.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Yeah. From the likes of them.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: It's your time mister. Fifteen minutes ain't long.  That cigarette burns out, your time is up.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: What's your name?

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: Easy.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: That ain't much of a name.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: It's easy to remember. Easy Lay.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: What's your real name?

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: I don't like my real name.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: What's your real name?

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: Iris.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: That's a nice name.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: That's what you think.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: Why? Who are you?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I drive a taxi. You tried to get away one night. Remember?

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: You tried to run away in my taxi but your friend -- Sport -- wouldn't let you.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: I don't remember.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: It don't matter. I'm gonna get you outta here.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: We better make it, or Sport'll get mad. How do you want to make it?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I don't want to make it. I came here to get you out.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: You want to make it like this?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Can't you listen to me? Don't you want to get out of here?

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: Why should I want to get out of here? This is where I live.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: But you're the one that wanted to get away. You're the one that came into my cab.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: I musta been stoned.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Do they drug you?

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: Oh, come off it, man.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Listen...

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: Don't you want to make it?  Can't you make it?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Fuck it! Fuck it! Fuck it! Fuck it! Fuck it! Fuck it! Fuck it!

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: You can do it in my mouth.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Don't you understand anything?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Do you understand why I came here?

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: I think so. I tried to get into your cab one night, and now you want to come and take me away.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Don't you want to go?

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: I can leave anytime I want.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: But that one night?

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: I was stoned. That's why they stopped me. When I'm not stoned, I got no place else to go. They just protect me from myself.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Well, I tried.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: I understand, mister. It means something, really.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Can I see you again?

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: That's not hard to do.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: No, I mean really. This is nothing for a person to do.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: Sure. All right. We'll have breakfast. I get up about one o'clock. Tomorrow.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Well tomorrow noon there's a... I got a...

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: Well, you want to or not?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: O.K. It's a date. I'll see you here, then.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: ...and after that Sport and I just started hanging out...

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Where is home?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: Pittsburgh.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I ain't ever been there, but it don't seem like such a bad place.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: Why do you want me to go back to my parents? They hate me. Why do you think I split? There ain't nothin there.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: But you can't live like this. It's hell. Girls should live at home.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: Didn't you ever hear of women's lib?

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: God, you are square.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: At least I don't walk the streets like a skunk pussy. I don't screw and fuck with killers and junkies.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: Who's a killer?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: That fella "Sport" looks like a killer to me.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: He never killed nobody. He's a Libra.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: I'm a Libra too. That's why we get along so well.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: He looks like a killer.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: I think Cancer's make the best lovers. My whole family are air signs.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: He shoots dope too.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: What makes you so high and mighty? Did you ever look at your own eyeballs in a mirror. You don't get eyes like that from...

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: He's worse than an animal. Jail's too good for scum like that.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: Rock music died in 1970, that's what I think. Before that it was fantastic. I can tell you that. Everybody was crashing, hanging out at the Fillmore. Me and my girlfriend Ann used to go up the fire escape, you know? It was unbelievable. Rock Stars everywhere. That Airplane -- that's my group, man. All Libras. But now everybody's split or got sick or busted. I think I'll move to one of those communes in Vermont, you know? That's where all the smart ones went. I stayed here.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I never been to a commune. I don't know. I saw pictures in a magazine, and it didn't look very clean to me.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: Why don't you come to a commune with me?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Me? I could never go to a place like that.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I... I don't get along with people like that.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: You a scorpion? That's it. You're a scorpion. I can tell.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Besides, I've got to stay here.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I've got something important to do. I can't leave.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: What's so important?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I can't say -- it's top secret. I'm doing something for the Army. The cab thing is just part time.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: You a narc?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Do I look like a narc?

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: God, I don't know who's weirder, you or me.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: What are you going to do about Sport and that old bastard?

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: Just leave'em. There's plenty of other girls.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: You just gonna leave 'em?

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: What should I do? Call the cops?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Cops don't do nothin.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: Sport never treated me bad, honest. Never beat me up once.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: You can't leave 'em to do the same to other girls. You should get rid of them.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I don't know. Just should, though.  Somebody should kill 'em. Nobody'd miss 'em.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: God. I know where they should have a commune for you. They should have a commune for you at Bellevue.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I'm sorry, Iris. I didn't mean that.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: You're not much with girls, are you?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Well, Iris, I look at it this way. A lot of girls come into my cab, some of them very beautiful. And I figure all day long men have been after them: trying to touch them, talk to them, ask them out. And they hate it. So I figure the best I can do for them is not bother them at all. So I don't say a thing. I pretend I'm not even there. I figure they'll understand that and appreciate me for it.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: Do you really think I should go to the commune?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I think you should go home, but otherwise I think you should go. It would be great for you. You have to get away from here. The city's a sewer, you gotta get out of it.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: Sure you don't want to come with me?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I can't. Otherwise, I would.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: I sure hate to go alone...

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I'll give you the money to go. I don't want you to take any from those guys.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: You don't have to.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I want to -- what else can I do with my money?  You may not see me again -- for a while.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: My work may take me out of New York.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Why should it be grounded?

turns.speaker: MAN IN BUSINESS SUIT
turns.text: Listen -- I mean I just saw the needle of the Empire State Building. You can't see it for the fog!

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Then it's a good guess it's grounded.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BUSINESS SUIT
turns.text: The Empire State in fog means something, don't it? Do you know, or don't you? What is your number, cabbie?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Have you tried the telephone?

turns.speaker: MAN IN BUSINESS SUIT
turns.text: There isn't time for that. In other words, you don't know.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BUSINESS SUIT
turns.text: Well, you should know, damn it, or who else would know? Pull over right here.  Why don't you stick your goddamn head out of the goddamn window once in a while and find out about the goddamn fog!

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Say, aren't you Charles Palantine, the candidate?

turns.speaker: PALANTINE
turns.text: Yes I am.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Well, I'm one of your biggest supporters. I tell everybody that comes in this cab that they should vote for you.

turns.speaker: PALANTINE
turns.text: Why, thank you Travis.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I'm sure you'll win, sir. Everybody I know is going to vote for you.  I was going to put one of your stickers on my taxi but the company said it was against their policy.

turns.speaker: PALANTINE
turns.text: I'll tell you, Travis, I've learned more about this country sitting in taxi cabs than in the board room of General Motors.

turns.speaker: PALANTINE
turns.text: Travis, what single thing would you want the next President of this country to do most?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I don't know, sir. I don't follow political issues much.

turns.speaker: PALANTINE
turns.text: There must be something...

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Well, he should clean up this city here. It's full of filth and scum. Scum and filth. It's like an open sewer. I can hardly take it. Some days I go out and smell it then I get headaches that just stay and never go away. We need a President that would clean up this whole mess. Flush it out.

turns.speaker: PALANTINE
turns.text: I know what you mean, Travis, and it's not going to be easy. We're going to have to make some radical changes.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Damn straight.

turns.speaker: PALANTINE
turns.text: Nice talking to you, Travis.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Thank you, sir. You're a good man, sir.

turns.speaker: PERSONNEL OFFICER
turns.text: No trouble with the Hack Bureau?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: No Sir.

turns.speaker: PERSONNEL OFFICER
turns.text: Got your license?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: PERSONNEL OFFICER
turns.text: So why do you want to be a taxi driver?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I can't sleep nights.

turns.speaker: PERSONNEL OFFICER
turns.text: There's porno theatres for that.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I know. I tried that.

turns.speaker: PERSONNEL OFFICER
turns.text: So whatja do now?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I ride around nights mostly. Subways, buses. See things. Figur'd I might as well get paid for it.

turns.speaker: PERSONNEL OFFICER
turns.text: We don't need any misfits around here, son.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: You kiddin? Who else would hack through South Bronx or Harlem at night?

turns.speaker: PERSONNEL OFFICER
turns.text: You want to work uptown nights?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I'll work anywhere, anytime. I know I can't be choosy.

turns.speaker: PERSONNEL OFFICER
turns.text: How's your driving record?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Clean. Real clean.  As clean as my conscience.

turns.speaker: PERSONNEL OFFICER
turns.text: Listen, son, you gonna get smart, you can leave right now.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Sorry, sir. I didn't mean that.

turns.speaker: PERSONNEL OFFICER
turns.text: Physical? Criminal?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Also clean.

turns.speaker: PERSONNEL OFFICER
turns.text: Age?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Twenty-six.

turns.speaker: PERSONNEL OFFICER
turns.text: Education?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Some. Here and there.

turns.speaker: PERSONNEL OFFICER
turns.text: Military record?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Honorable discharge. May 1971.

turns.speaker: PERSONNEL OFFICER
turns.text: You moonlightin?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: No, I want long shifts.

turns.speaker: PERSONNEL OFFICER
turns.text: We hire a lot of moonlighters here.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: So I hear.

turns.speaker: PERSONNEL OFFICER
turns.text: Hell, we ain't that much fussy anyway. There's always opening on one fleet or another.  Fill out these forms and give them to the girl at the desk, and leave your phone number. You gotta phone?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: PERSONNEL OFFICER
turns.text: Well then check back tomorrow.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Yes, Sir.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Are you a Secret Service Man?

turns.speaker: SECRET SERVICE MAN
turns.text: Why do you ask?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I've seen a lot of suspicious-looking people around here today.

turns.speaker: SECRET SERVICE MAN
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Oh, lots. I don't know where they all are now. There used to be one standing over there.

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: Is it hard to get to be a Secret Service Man?

turns.speaker: SECRET SERVICE MAN
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I kinda thought I might make a good one. I'm very observant.

turns.speaker: SECRET SERVICE MAN
turns.text: Oh?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: I was in the Army too.  And I'm good with crowds.

turns.speaker: SECRET SERVICE MAN
turns.text: Is that so?

turns.speaker: TRAVIS
turns.text: What kind of guns do you guys use? .38's?
